verses.text: In the thirty-sixth year of Asa’s reign, Baasha king of Israel went up against Judah and built Ramah, so that he could prevent anyone from going out or coming in to Asa king of Judah.
verses.comment: ‘Built Ramah’ preserves the meaning that Baasha fortified the city as a blockade.

verses.text: Then Asa brought out silver and gold from the treasuries of the house of the LORD and the king’s house and sent them to Ben-Hadad king of Aram, who lived in Damascus, saying:
verses.comment: ‘Ben-Hadad king of Aram’ uses the modern name for the region; ‘house’ translates as ‘palace’ in some versions.

verses.text: "Let there be a treaty between me and you, as there was between my father and your father. See, I am sending you silver and gold. Go, break your treaty with Baasha king of Israel so that he will withdraw from me."
verses.comment: Literal rendering of Asa’s diplomatic request.

verses.text: Ben-Hadad listened to King Asa and sent the commanders of his armies against the cities of Israel; they struck Ijon, Dan, Abel Maim, and all the storage cities of Naphtali.
verses.comment: ‘Abel Maim’ corresponds to ‘Abel Beth Maacah’ in Kings; rendered according to Chronicles’ wording.

verses.text: When Baasha heard of it, he stopped building Ramah and abandoned his work.
Then King Asa took all Judah, and they carried away the stones and timber of Ramah that Baasha was using for building. With them he built Geba and Mizpah.
verses.comment: Literal reading; ‘with them he built’ shows reuse of building materials.

verses.text: At that time Hanani the seer came to Asa king of Judah and said to him, "Because you relied on the king of Aram and did not rely on the LORD your God, the army of the king of Aram has escaped from your hand."
verses.comment: ‘Seer’ is updated from traditional ‘prophet’ to match the Hebrew Ro’eh.

verses.text: "Were not the Cushites and Libyans a huge army, with very many chariots and horsemen? Yet because you relied on the LORD, he gave them into your hand."
verses.comment: ‘Cushites and Libyans’ maintains the ethnic references from the original text.

verses.text: "For the eyes of the LORD roam throughout the whole earth to strengthen those whose hearts are fully committed to him. You have done foolishly in this; from now on, you will have wars."
verses.comment: ‘The eyes of the LORD roam’ is a literal rendering; ‘fully committed’ for ‘perfect’ heart.

verses.text: Then Asa was angry with the seer and put him in prison, for he was enraged at him about this. And Asa oppressed some of the people at that time.
verses.comment: ‘Prison’ is literal; ‘oppressed’ preserves strong negative action against the people.

verses.text: Now the acts of Asa, first and last, are written in the Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Book of the Kings’ preserves ancient text reference.

verses.text: In the thirty-ninth year of his reign, Asa became diseased in his feet. His disease was very serious, yet even in his sickness he did not seek the LORD, but turned to physicians.
And Asa slept with his fathers; he died in the forty-first year of his reign.
verses.comment: ‘Slept with his fathers’ is idiom for death, as in original.

verses.text: They buried him in his own tomb that he had carved for himself in the city of David, and laid him on a bed full of spices and various perfumes prepared by the perfumer’s art; and they made a very great fire in his honor.
verses.comment: ‘Made a very great fire’ refers to the funeral fire, as per ancient burial custom.
